briefing.opening: Good morning. I will now begin the climate briefing for February 4, 2026.

sections.title: ğŸ”´ Deepening Climate Crisis and Vulnerability
sections.content: Today's climate-related news highlighted the direct impacts of the deepening global climate crisis and the resulting vulnerabilities. An analysis suggested that last month's cold weather in Korea was due to the southward movement of cold air caused by a weakening polar vortex [11], and in the U.S., reports indicated that the combination of climate change and human psychology made cold waves feel even more severe [100, 110]. Cuba is facing a double challenge with its first-ever 0-degree Celsius record due to climate change [8], and extreme weather events, such as a bomb cyclone hitting Virginia, are becoming more frequent [105]. Furthermore, drought and climate change are affecting well water quality, fish populations in Wisconsin, and even the success of the Australian Winter Olympics [103, 104, 107], and in Pakistan, a humanitarian crisis has emerged with 58 deaths due to desert encroachment [120]. Domestically, criticism has been raised that the Korea Forest Service is implementing policies detached from reality, such as planting 'climate-vulnerable species' for afforestation despite the climate crisis [13].

sections.title: ğŸ‡°ğŸ‡· Domestic Climate Policies and Legal Challenges
sections.content: Domestically, policy discussions and legal challenges for responding to climate change are ongoing. The deadline for amending the Carbon Neutrality Act, which was ruled 'unconstitutional non-conformity,' was missed, putting its processing at risk of being postponed to May [23], and the necessity for public deliberation on this matter has been raised [26, 32, 51]. There is also a movement led by the National Assembly to launch a Climate Crisis Response Deliberation Committee to secure legislative legitimacy for setting the NDC (Nationally Determined Contribution) [50]. Meanwhile, an independent bill for climate crisis 'adaptation' has been proposed, driving a comprehensive overhaul of the disaster response system [12], and Jeollanam-do Province is strengthening regional-level response efforts, including actively pursuing the establishment of a Marine and Fisheries Climate Change Response Center [2]. The Korea Forest Service clarified its stance on the 'climate-vulnerable species' afforestation controversy and stated its position on discovering climate-resilient tree species [6].

sections.title: ğŸŒ± Efforts for Carbon Neutrality and Renewable Energy Transition
sections.content: Domestic and international efforts for achieving carbon neutrality and transitioning to renewable energy are actively underway. Ulju-gun is promoting the supply of new and renewable energy facilities, such as solar and geothermal power, to 200 locations within its region [53, 93], and Haenam-gun has initiated the creation of a renewable energy citizen fund to return energy profits to the local community [55, 96]. With the path opened for data centers to directly purchase renewable energy (PPA) [84], Shinseong E&G and Bridge Ocean Consulting are collaborating on renewable energy infrastructure for data centers, and companies like LG Uplus and GS E&C are also signing renewable energy supply contracts for data centers, thus expanding corporate utilization of renewable energy [56, 58, 95]. Furthermore, Buyeo-gun is accelerating its transition to a carbon-neutral city by commencing construction of hydrogen charging stations [34, 41], and Gyeongsangbuk-do Province is leading carbon-neutral infrastructure development by promoting the construction of a hydrogen energy highway [45, 47]. The Australian government is strengthening national-level support by launching a $5 billion Net Zero Fund to decarbonize industries and foster manufacturing growth [119].

sections.title: ğŸŒ Climate Change Adaptation and International Cooperation
sections.content: International adaptation efforts and cooperation discussions on climate change are also active. Korea and the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) are discussing a 'Great Ocean States' climate strategy, thereby initiating Caribbean cooperation [3], and the EU Delegation to Korea and GEYK held a youth forum to explore 'win-win' solutions for renewable energy and biodiversity [19, 59, 82]. The Korean and Japanese life insurance industries held a seminar to jointly address the common threats of a super-aged society and climate change, seeking collaborative response measures [5, 18]. The World Wide Fund for Nature (WWF) is raising public awareness by widely publicizing the climate change damage suffered by polar bears through its endangered animal protection campaign [1]. Additionally, discussions were held on how developing countries can shape the climate change agenda [106], and the Virginia House of Delegates passed a bill to rejoin climate change agreements, showing a move to participate in international climate response efforts [99]. An article also reported on the inadequate climate change adaptation in the Netherlands and Bonaire, reminding us of the importance of adaptation efforts [108].

briefing.closing: As you have seen in today's briefing, the climate crisis is comprehensively impacting our lives and systems, but at the same time, various policy efforts, technological advancements, and international cooperation to overcome it are continuously underway. This concludes today's climate briefing.
